definition[0]: used to refer to a person, thing, idea etc that has just been mentioned or to something that has just happened
example[0]: We must make sure this doesn’t happen again.
example[1]: Is there any way of solving these problems?
example[2]: If young Daly continues to improve at this rate, he’ll soon be in the A Team.
example[3]: This will be discussed in the next chapter.
example[4]: This boyfriend of yours – how old is he?
definition[1]: used to talk about the present time or a time that is close to the present
example[5]: There will be another meeting later this week.
example[6]: This has been the worst year of my life.
example[7]: I thought he would have been back before this.
example[8]: We’ll be seeing Malcolm this Friday  (=on Friday of the present week).
example[9]: I’m sorry I was late this morning  (=today in the morning).
example[10]: Everyone seems to be in a hurry these days (=at the present period).
example[11]: I want to see you in my office this minute (=immediately).
definition[2]: used to talk about the present situation
example[12]: I hate this cold damp weather.
example[13]: Things have never been as bad as this before.
definition[3]: used to talk about a thing or person that is near you, the thing you are holding, or the place where you are
example[14]: These are your gloves, aren’t they?
example[15]: You have to park on this side of the road.
example[16]: I can’t bear the atmosphere in this house much longer.
definition[4]: used to refer to something that you are going to say or that is just about to happen
example[18]: Wait till you hear this joke.
example[19]: This is going to surprise you.
definition[5]: used in stories, jokes etc when you mention a person or thing for the first time
example[20]: I met this really weird guy last night.
example[21]: Suddenly, there was this tremendous bang.
definition[6]: used to introduce someone to someone else
example[22]: Sam, this is my sister, Liz.
definition[7]: used to give your name when you are speaking on the telephone
example[23]: ‘Can I speak to Joan, please?’ ‘This is Joan speaking.’
definition[8]: used to say how big, how much etc, when you are showing the size, amount etc with your hands
example[24]: The table’s about this high and this wide.
example[25]: You need to cut about this much off the end of the pipe.
definition[9]: as good, bad, much etc as in the present situation
example[26]: I hadn’t realised that things had got this bad.
example[27]: I’ve never had this much money before.
